sen.j: 武田 国信（たけだ くにのぶ、嘉吉2年（1442年）- 延徳2年6月21日 (旧暦)（1490年7月8日））は室町時代の大名。
sen.e: Kuninobu TAKEDA (1442-June 21, 1490, in the old lunar calendar; July 8, 1490) was daimyo of the Muromachi period.
Kuninobu TAKEDA (1442 - July 17, 1490) was a daimyo of the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 武田氏若狭武田氏の第3代当主。
sen.e: Kuninobu TAKEDA was the third family head of the WAKASA-TAKEDA clan (the TAKEDA clan of Wakasa Province).
sen.cmt: 「武田氏若狭武田氏」と同一の言い回しは探しうるどの文献にも見あたりません。「武田氏（若狭武田氏）」として解釈しています。
sen.e: He was the third family head of the Wakasa-Takeda clan (the Takeda clan of Wakasa Province).
sen.cmt: 原文には 「武田氏若狭武田氏」とありましたが、リンク先の単語のようです。ウェブで確認すると用語が「若狭武田氏」となっており、本来はこちらの用語を使用していると思われますので、こちらを訳出し、原文修正しました。
sen.e: He was the third family head of the Wakasa-Takeda clan (the Takeda clan of Wakasa Province).

sen.j: 武田氏安芸武田氏の武田信繁 (室町時代)の三男で、武田信栄や武田信賢の弟。
sen.e: Kuninobu TAKEDA was born as the third son of Nobushige TAKEDA (the Muromachi period) belonging to the AKI-TAKEDA clan (the TAKEDA clan of Aki Province), and was a younger brother of Nobuhide TAKEDA and Nobukata TAKEDA.
sen.cmt: 上記同様、「武田氏安芸武田氏」と同一の言い回しは探しうるどの文献にも見あたりません。「武田氏（安芸武田氏）」として解釈しています。
sen.e: He was born as the third son of Nobushige TAKEDA (the Muromachi period) belonging to the Aki-Takeda clan (the TAKEDA clan of Aki Province), and was a younger brother of Nobuhide TAKEDA and Nobukata TAKEDA.
sen.cmt: 原文には 「武田氏安芸武田氏」とありましたが、リンク先の単語のようです。ウェブで確認すると用語が「安芸武田氏」となっており、本来はこちらの用語を使用していると思われますので、こちらを訳出し、原文修正しました。

sen.j: 1471年（文明2年）兄の信賢の死去後、武田氏の家督を継ぐ。
sen.e: Following the death of his elder brother Nobukata in 1471, Kuninobu took over as head of the TAKEDA family.
Following the death of his older brother Nobukata in 1471, Kuninobu took over as head of the Takeda clan.

sen.j: 信賢に嫡子はいたが、幼少であったため、国信が家督を継ぐこととなる（この信賢の嫡子が武田信広とする伝承がある）。
sen.e: Instead of Nobukata's infant legitimate son, Kuninobu took over as head of the family (a legend says that that Nobukata's legitimate son would be Nobuhiro TAKEDA).

sen.j: 応仁の乱では兄の信賢同様に細川勝元の東軍に属して、土岐成頼らの西軍と戦うなど奮戦している。
sen.e: In the Onin War, Kuninobu TAKEDA, like his elder brother Nobukata, joined the 'eastern' army led by Katsumoto HOSOKAWA and fought bravely with the 'western' army troops including Shigeyori TOKI.

sen.j: しかし弟武田元綱の離反にも遭うなど苦戦も強いられている。
sen.e: However, Kuninobu also faced a hard time when his younger brother Mototsuna TAKEDA turned against him.

sen.j: 1475年（文明6年）4月、山名政豊と細川政元の和睦の仲介役を務める。
sen.e: In April, 1475, Kuninobu TAKEDA, serving as a mediator, reconciled Masatoyo YAMANA with Masamoto HOSOKAWA.
In April, 1474, Kuninobu, serving as a mediator, reconciled Masatoyo YAMANA with Masamoto HOSOKAWA.
sen.cmt: 文明6年は1474年なので、旧暦に基づき変更しました。
sen.e: In April, 1474, Kuninobu, serving as a mediator, reconciled Masatoyo YAMANA with Masamoto HOSOKAWA.

sen.j: しかしこのときの和睦の条件の一つとして、武田氏が応仁の乱の最中に一色氏と戦って奪った丹後国の所領を返還せよという条件があった。
sen.e: This reconciliation between YAMANA and HOSOKAWA, however, was made based on some conditions, one of which was to return the fief of Tango Province that the TAKEDA clan had deprived the Isshiki clan of during the Onin War.

sen.j: 丹後に在陣中の武田氏被官人はこれに不満で所領返還を拒んだが、和睦に参加した国信は援軍を丹後に送ることができなかった。
sen.e: Although the discontented hikan (dependent retainer) of the TAKEDA clan had been in their Tango camp and refused the return of the fief, Kuninobu, who had joined the reconciliation, was unable to dispatch troop reinforcements to Tango.

sen.j: 丹後の武田勢は独力で一色氏と戦わざるを得ず、9月に主将逸見真正は自害、武田軍は敗れて壊滅してしまった。
sen.e: Therefore, the TAKEDA's army in Tango was obliged to fight with the ISSHIKI clan on their own, and the chief commander 真正 HENMI committed suicide in September, which resulted in the defeat and destruction of the TAKEDA's army.
sen.cmt: 逸見「真正」 名の読み不明。
sen.e: Therefore, the Takeda's army in Tango was obliged to fight with the Isshiki clan on their own, and the chief commander Masatada (真正) HENMI committed suicide in October, which resulted in the defeat and destruction of the Takeda's army.
sen.cmt: 表記を変えました。また「文明6年9月」としてグレゴリオ暦に直しました。

sen.j: 国信はこのとき、落胆して出家し、宗勲と号したという。
sen.e: Then Kuninobu in despair entered the priesthood and was given the priest name Sokun.

sen.j: その後、足利義尚の六角氏討伐（六角征伐）に従って出陣した。
sen.e: Thereafter, Sokun (Kuninobu) TAKEDA followed Yoshihisa ASHIKAGA, who embarked on a punitive expedition against the ROKKAKU clan (ROKKAKU seibatsu or a military campaign against the ROKKAKU clan).

sen.j: だが、1490年（延徳2年6月21日）、小浜で病死した。
sen.e: Sokun (Kuninobu) TAKEDA died of illness in Obama Province on June 21, 1490.

sen.e: As Sokun (Kuninobu) TAKEDA's legitimate son Nobuchika had already passed away in 1484, the other son Motonobu succeeded him.

sen.j: 1545年、久松山城（後の鳥取城）を改築したが、あまりに堅固過ぎたため、主君より謀叛の疑念を買い謀殺された。
sen.e: In 1545, Kuninobu TAKEDA refurbished Kyushozan-jo Castle (to be later called Tottori-jo Castle), but this substantial fortress triggered the master's fear of treachery, thus resulting in the premeditated murder of Kuninobu.

sen.j: 1546年10月、伯耆国の南条宗勝を助けて橋津川の戦いで尼子氏と戦った因幡山名氏の重臣として「武田豊前守常信」の名が記録に残るが、武田国信と同一人物だったかは不明（同一人物と見る説も存在する）。
sen.e: A record shows the name 'TAKEDA Buzen-no-kami Tsunenobu' as a senior vassal of the YAMANA clan of Inaba Province, who had fought against the AMAKO clan at the Battle of Hashizugawa in an attempt to support Munekatsu NANJO of Hoki Province in October, 1546, but it is unknown whether that person was identical with Kuninobu TAKEDA (N.B. There exists a theory that the TAKEDA Buzen-no-kami Tsunenobu was identical with Kuninobu TAKEDA).

A record shows the name 'Takeda Buzen no kami Tsunenobu' as a senior vassal of the Inaba-Yamana clan, who had fought against the Amago clan at the Battle of Hashizugawa in an attempt to support Munekatsu NANJO of Hoki Province in October, 1546, but it is unknown whether that person was identical with Kuninobu TAKEDA (other theory sees they were the same person).
